title: Craters on our Earth and Other Planets
text: In this exercise students use the Impact Calculator lab to investigate what happens when a comet it hits the Earth.
description: In this exercise students use the Impact Calculator lab to investigate what happens when a comet it hits the Earth.

phases.title: Orientation
phases.description: In this exercise students use the Impact Calculator lab to investigate what happens when a comet it hits the Earth.

items.content: Ever wondered what would happen if an asteroid or comet hit Earth?
Have a look at the following video for an example.

Does Hollywood show accurately what this would do to our home? Well now is your chance to find out!

Let's have a quick look at some recent events like the Chelyabinsk meteor.

Food for Thought

Did you know that the asteroid that wiped out the dinosaurs is said to have been roughly 10km in diameter? It hit the Earth around 65 million years ago and left a crater about 180km wide.

phases.title: Conceptualisation
phases.description: What parameters should we take into consideration when investigating asteroid collisions?

phases.title: Exploration
phases.description: In order to do our investigation we will use the Down2Earth Impact Calculator. The Down2Earth Impact Calculator can simulate an impactor of a specific size and density, travelling at a certain velocity and given trajectory angle. Given the density of Earth rock that the impactor hits, this program can then simulate the effects which follow.

phases.title: Discussion
phases.description:
Communication

Comment on how well your investigation went. How accurate do you think the software is? Does it have any limitations? If you were to repeat this investigation, how would you improve it?

Reflection

Share your results with others in the class.

Comment on any similarities/differences between your results and others.

Think about how you individually carried out the activity and what you might change in future investigations which may affect your results.

phases.title: Conclusion
phases.description:
From the analysis carried out above, summarize the main conclusions for your investigation i.e. how does changing the impact angle of the impactor affect the size and volume of the crater formed?

Look back to your original hypotheses and compare them to your conclusions.

Do your results agree with your conclusions? Identify any mistakes you might have made while making your hypothesis.

Note down your answers in order to produce your report.

title: Series and Parallel Circuits
text: The challenge of this lesson is to determine how the light fixtures in a house are connected, in series or in parallel? Your task is to perform a scientific investigation in order to provide enough arguments for the appropriate setup.
description: The challenge of this lesson is to determine how the light fixtures in a house are connected, in series or in parallel? Your task is to perform a scientific investigation in order to provide enough arguments for the appropriate setup.

title: Sinking and Floating
text: In this ILS students can learn about properties of objects that influence whether an object sinks or floats in the water. They get the assignment to find out which materials they can use to build a raft that floats in order to leave the island they are currently on. By going through all phases of inquiry they will gain knowledge about mass, volume and density, and their relation to each other.
description: In this ILS students can learn about properties of objects that influence whether an object sinks or floats in the water. title: Discovering Acidity
description: In this lesson, you will learn why coffee is acid and soap basic. Isn't that fascinating?

items.content: The British scientist, Humphrey Davy (1778-1829), better known for his studies into gases, tested the theories of Lavoisier and discovered that oxygen was not the element responsible for the properties of acids.

title: Capacitors
description: In this lesson, you will learn why coffee is acid and soap basic. Isn't that fascinating?

items.content: The British scientist, Humphrey Davy (1778-1829), better known for his studies into gases, tested the theories of Lavoisier and discovered that oxygen was not the element responsible for the properties of acids.

title: Exploring the pH Scale
description: Did you know that even though the sting of both a wasp and a bee hurt a lot, they should be cured using different remedies? More specifically, on a wasp sting one has to apply vinegar, whereas a bee sting is relieved with the application of ammonia.

phases.title: Orientation
phases.description: In this lesson, you will test the pH of 11 different liquids from everyday life, such as blood, spit, soda pop, battery acid and water, through the use of a virtual pH meter. Throughout this activity you will be asked to answer a number of questions that require critical thinking and link the concept of pH to real life, like why does drinking soda pop help soothe a tummy ache.

items.content: Have a look at the following video for an example.
To measure the acidity or alkalinity of a solution, scientists use a universal indicator in the form of a liquid or paper. The colour indicates the pH value.

Food for Thought

Did you know that even though the sting of both a wasp and a bee hurt a lot, they should be cured using different remedies? More specifically, on a wasp sting one has to apply vinegar, whereas a bee sting is relieved with the application of ammonia.
